data.definition: Related to modern Italian embracciare "to embrace". Unarmed combat, including strikes, grabs, throws, takedowns, join locks and chokes.
One of the four types of footwork in the dei Liberi tradition, analogous to the advancing step of modern fencing.
Arte dell'armizare (the art of arms) is the closest dei Liberi comes to giving his art a formal name.
Dei Liberi defines seven blows, six cuts (taglii) and the thrust (punta).
Descending, diagonal cuts that follow the line from the teeth or jaw line  to the knees. Fendente are made with the true edge

Horizontal cuts that can be made anywhere from the knee to the head, but are particularly aimed at the neck/throat. Middle blows are made with the true edge from the forehand side and with the false edge from the backhand side.

Diagonal rising cuts that follow the same path as the fendenti. Vadi advises only using the true edge for the forehand sottano, but dei Liberi's instructions allow for the false edge to be used for either.
A counter technique
Any defensive action that closes the line of an attack, thereby protecting the combatant. Parries (parrate) are a subset of coverta.
One of the four types of footwork in dei Liberi's art, analogous to the retreat in modern fencing

data.translation: A guard or position from which one may attack or defend. See poste

data.definition: Any crossing of weapons, arms, etc., such as when a sword is parried. Del Liberi says that crossings can happen in three places with a weapon: the point (punta), middle (mezza), or hilt (tutta).

A range in combat with long weapons that bridges wide and close play (zogho largo and zogho stretto). Understanding the "half-sword" is critically important, because all actions: cuts, thrusts, hilt strikes, grapples, throws, etc., are possible.

One of the three turns of the body (volta del corpo) and of the sword (volta della spada). As a step, the mezza volta is a passing step that turns the combatant's body so that his strong side is reversed, i.e. a man in a right lead has his strong side to the left.
An interposition or deflection made with/by the sword. First use appears in Vadi. A subset of coverta, it includes the rebatter.
On of the four types of footwork in dei Libari's system, where the rear foot steps forward in front of the lead foot, "passing" it.
Used nearly interchangeably with guardia, a posta is a position of readiness from which the scholar may strike, defend or hold his ground.
The term can be used variously to mean anything from a simple grip, such as the enemy's sword hilt, to a full -out wresting hold or play of abrazare.
Both the name of the end of the sword, and a thrust madw with the point.

A percussive strike made to deflect an attack, generally either driving it back towards the attacker, or redirect it into the earth. The rebatter can be used as a parry or a preemptive attack on the opponent's weapons.
One of dei Liberi's four types of footwork. A passing step backwards, the lead foot steps back behind the rear foot, passing it.
The term has various meanings. For example, a guard can be "broken" by threatening the opponent so that they are forced to change guards, while an attack can be broken by driving it into the earth.
Overhand
Underhand
Sword
A longsword, as distinguished from the spadone or gigantic Renaissance two-handed sword.

One of dei Liberi's three types of turn (volta), where one foot moves circularly around the other, turning the scholar's facing by 180 degrees. The tutta volta of the sword is when the sword strikes from one side of the opponent's weapon to the other. For example, if the swords were crossed on the inside line, the scholar would strike around the other weapon to the outside line.

Dei Liberi describes turns (steps used to change the body's facing): the stable turn (volta stabile), half turn (mezza volta) and full turn (tutta volta). These turns can also be applied to the motion of the sword. The term volta also means "time" in Italian, and the longer the volta, the longer the time (tempo) it takes to execute.
One of the three volte, the stable turn is a simple shift from a forward to a backward-weighted stance and vice-versa, allowing the swordsman to play in any direction on one side.

A style of play with long weapons (sword, spear and axe) meant to keep the scholar at a distance. Plays of zogho largo occur at wide distance through the half-sword, and utilize long range attacks: strikes with the weapon's edge and point, kicks, blade grabs and prese of the hand and forearm.

A style of play with or without weapons with can bring the players into body-to-body contact. Plays of zogho stretto begin at the half-sword and utilize close range attacks: strokes with the weapon's hilt, hand, elbow and knee grappling and throws.
